Q: How to create a Datadog monitor for Kubernetes container restarts strictly due to OOM? A:

I'm doing this using an event monitor, rather than a metric monitor.
events(source:containerd event_type:oom).rollup(count).by(pod_name,kube_namespace).last(5m) >= 1

Q: iPadOS 26 how to set different orientations in different view controllers A:

This is basically Apple changing the rules on iPad, not your code breaking randomly.

What used to work was kind of a loophole. When iPad moved fully to scenes and multitasking, orientation stopped being something a pushed VC can force. iPhone still allows it, iPad doesn't, especially if the app isn’t full screen.

supportedInterfaceOrientations now just means “if the system decides to rotate, these are ok”. It does not mean “rotate right now”.
prefersInterfaceOrientationLocked only locks whatever orientation you're already in.

Your old approach worked because UIRequiresFullScreen gave you control of the whole screen. Once that’s gone, Apple just ignores VC-level forcing on iPad.

For a landscape-only mini game (especially with gyro), the supported solution is to present it full screen, not push it:

let vc = LandscapeVC()
vc.modalPresentationStyle = .fullScreen
present(vc, animated: true)

When you dismiss it, you’re back to portrait automatically. No hacks, no app delegate tricks, works on iPadOS 26.

If you really want it inside nav, there’s honestly no clean supported way anymore. Apple wants games, video, AR, etc to be full screen or in their own scene.

Q: Passing a local reference to a closure A:

Is the code above incorrect?

TL;DR:

The code is valid.

More info:

In C++ there is no such thing as a reference to a reference.
Here t is a reference to an element in the vector, and when you capture it by reference in the lambda, you are not capturing a local by ref, but rather keep a reference to the element in the vector (a reference to a reference is the same as the original reference).

Notes:

  1. Your title ("Passing a local reference ...") - is not entirely correct: as explained above the reference is not really to a local (otherwise it would have become dangling).

  2. The validity of the code relies on the fact that the vector here outlives the lambdas (otherwise the capture becomes dangling).

  3. Some related additional information about the state in the standard can be found in @Yakk-AdamNevraumont's answer here: Lambda capturing rvalue reference by reference.
